title: Javad Zarif: Main threat to the Middle East is Israel, not Iran
summary: Iran’s former foreign minister argues Israel, backed by the US, has killed every opportunity for peace.

title: Protests turn deadly during demonstration in Syrian city of Latakia
summary: Fighting has broken out at a demonstration in the city of Latakia in Syria, killing at least three people.

title: Niger’s military rulers order ‘general mobilisation’ against armed groups
summary: Military rulers expand emergency powers, warning that people, property, and services may be requisitioned.

title: One year in Israeli detention, Dr Hussam Abu Safia’s son pleads for release
summary: Israel has held Gaza doctor Hussam Abu Safia for an entire year without charge.

title: Syria protests live: Deadly clashes erupt as hundreds demonstrate
summary: Hundreds of people take to the streets in Tartous and Latakia to demand the release of former soldiers.

title: Video: What do Rohingya refugees think about Myanmar’s election?
summary: Myanmar's election is unlikely to change the reality for more than 1M Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh.

title: US-Israel ties: What Netanyahu and Trump will discuss in Florida
summary: Trump to host Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago amid Washington's push for phase two of Gaza ceasefire as strategy gaps grow.

title: Gaza storm kills Palestinian woman as Israeli curbs on aid compound misery
summary: Extreme weather leaves thousands homeless as tents collapse amid strong wind and heavy rain.

title: LIVE: Sabalenka vs Kyrgios: ‘Battle of the Sexes’ tennis match
summary: Follow the build-up, analysis and live text commentary of the exhibition mixed singles tennis match in Dubai.

title: Somalia condemns Israel’s recognition of Somaliland as ‘naked invasion’
summary: Somalia's president calls for unity at emergency session of parliament, which declares the Israeli move 'null and void'.

title: Video: Israel slammed for recognising breakaway region of Somaliland
summary: Several countries and regional blocs have condemned Israel's recognition of Somaliland, a breakaway region of Somalia.

title: Libya lays army chief of staff to rest in Misrata
summary: Five officers, including chief of staff General al-Haddad, were flying from Turkiye to Libya when their plane crashed.

title: Syrie : plusieurs manifestants alaouites tués par les forces de l'ordre
summary: Des milliers de manifestants appartenant à la communauté alaouite sont descendus dans la rue, dimanche, en Syrie, deux jours après l'attaque d'une de leurs mosquées qui a fait huit morts. Au moins trois personnes ont été tuées par les forces de l'ordre, alors qu'elles dispersaient un rassemblement dans la ville côtière de Lattaquié.

title: Iran-Israël : le récit des 12 jours de guerre ouverte
summary: Du 13 au 24 juin 2025, Israël et l’Iran s'affrontent à coups de missiles et de frappes aériennes. Un conflit qui affaiblit considérablement la République islamique, touche durement certaines villes israéliennes et dont l'issue est décidée dans le Bureau ovale. En lettres capitales sur son réseau social, c'est Donald Trump qui lui a donné son nom : “La guerre des douze jours”. Récit.

title: Yémen : l'Arabie saoudite menace les séparatistes d'une action militaire
summary: "Dans le but de protéger la vie des civils", l'Arabie saoudite a menacé, samedi, d'une action militaire les séparatistes du Conseil de transition du sud au Yémen. Riyad, qui soutient le gouvernement yéménite, a appelé le STC à se retirer "pacifiquement" des provinces récemment conquises de Hadramout et Mahra.

title: Syrie : huit morts lors d'un attentat dans une mosquée à Homs
summary: Une explosion a frappé vendredi une mosquée située dans un secteur alaouite de la ville de Homs en Syrie, faisant huit morts, dernière attaque en date visant cette communauté musulmane minoritaire dans le pays.

title: Yémen : 15 000 combattants yéménites soutenus par l'Arabie saoudite massés à la frontière
summary: L'Arabie saoudite a été accusée vendredi par les séparatistes yéménites d'avoir bombardé leurs positions dans l'est du pays, un territoire dont ils se sont emparés le mois dernier. Quelque 15 000 militaires soutenus par l'Arabie saoudite sont également regroupés à la frontière depuis le début du mois, sans ordre d'avancer, a annoncé un responsable militaire.

title: Un Palestinien tue deux personnes dans le nord d'Israël
summary: Un Palestinien a attaqué vendredi deux personnes dans le nord d'Israël avant d'être blessé par des tirs. Une femme et un homme ont été tués, selon les secours israéliens et la police. Le ministre de la Défense israélien a demandé à l'armée d'agir "avec force" contre le village de l'assaillant.

title: Un groupuscule extrémiste sunnite revendique l'attaque contre une mosquée en Syrie
summary: ‍Au moins huit personnes ​ont été tuées, et 18 blessées vendredi dans une explosion qui a frappé une mosquée alaouite de Homs, dans l'ouest de la Syrie. Revendiquée par un groupuscule extrémiste sunnite dans un message posté sur Telegram, l'attaque a été condamnée par l'Onu et plusieurs pays de la région, ainsi que par la France, qui dénonce une tentative de déstabilisation.

title: Pour les chrétiens de Syrie, un Noël malgré les blessures, le deuil et l'inquiétude
summary: Un an après la chute du régime de Bachar al-Assad, les festivités de Noël se déroulent cette année sous le signe du deuil et de l’inquiétude pour les chrétiens de Syrie. À Damas et dans le village de Maaloula, la communauté chrétienne tente de célébrer, malgré les cicatrices laissées par les violences et un climat d’insécurité persistant.

title: Israël dit avoir tué un combattant de la force iranienne Al-Qods dans une frappe au Liban
summary: L'armée israélienne a annoncé avoir tué jeudi au Liban un "terroriste" de la force Al-Qods, branche des opérations extérieures des Gardiens de la révolution iraniens. Israël l'accusait de planifier des attaques "depuis la Syrie et le Liban".

title: Reconnaissance de la Palestine en 2025 : une victoire diplomatique, et après ?
summary: La reconnaissance de l’État de Palestine par plusieurs pays occidentaux en septembre, à l’initiative de la France, s'impose comme l'un des événements diplomatiques de l'année 2025. Ce tournant essentiellement symbolique pour les Palestiniens peut-il marquer la fin d’une impasse géopolitique vieille de plusieurs décennies ?

title: Noël à Gaza : une seule église reste debout dans l'enclave
summary: A Gaza, les fidèles se réunissent dans la seule église encore debout dans l'enclave devastée par la guerre.

title: Fêtes de Noël à Taybeh, seul village entièrement chrétien de Cisjordanie
summary: Père Bashar Fawadleh, Curé de l'Eglise latine de Taybeh, est notre invité.

title: L’Iran lance de Russie trois satellites d’observation, signe du développement de ses activités aérospatiales
summary: Ces satellites seront placés en orbite à 500 kilomètres de la Terre et auront une durée de vie de trois à cinq ans. Les gouvernements occidentaux craignent que ces systèmes de lancement intègrent des technologies interchangeables avec celles qui sont utilisées dans les missiles balistiques capables de livrer une ogive nucléaire.

title: En Espagne, trois personnes portées disparues après des pluies diluviennes près de Malaga
summary: L’agence météorologique nationale espagnole a abaissé de rouge à orange son niveau d’alerte en Andalousie, mais les fortes pluies se concentrent désormais sur le littoral de la région de Valence, déjà endeuillée il y a un peu plus d’un an par des inondations.

title: EN DIRECT, guerre en Ukraine : Volodymyr Zelensky est arrivé en Floride pour sa réunion avec Donald Trump
summary: Le président ukrainien a atterri à Miami, quelques heures avant sa rencontre avec le président américain, prévue à 19 heures (heure de Paris) à Palm Beach, rapportent les médias ukrainiens. Selon Kiev, un appel téléphonique entre des dirigeants européens et les présidents ukrainien et américain est prévu dans la foulée.

title: En Syrie, les forces de sécurité tuent deux personnes en dispersant une manifestation alaouite, selon l’OSDH
summary: Des milliers de Syriens alaouites ont participé, dimanche, à des manifestations dans plusieurs villes pour réclamer la fin des violences à la suite de l’attaque meurtrière d’une mosquée de cette communauté musulmane minoritaire dans le pays survenue à Homs vendredi.

title: Radoslaw Sikorski, vice-premier ministre de Pologne : « Le défi de l’UE consiste à traduire son poids économique en influence et en leadership mondiaux »
summary: Le ministre des affaires étrangères polonais appelle, dans une tribune au « Monde », au renfort de la coopération européenne en matière de sécurité, de migration, de technologie et de politique étrangère et à une alliance occidentale accrue avec les Etats-Unis.

title: Dans la bande de Gaza, des centaines de milliers d’hommes, femmes et enfants vivent dans des tentes, sous la pluie et le vent glacial
summary: La défense civile a averti de l’imminence d’une « nouvelle dépression », attendue dans les prochaines heures, avec « de fortes pluies et des vents violents » qui dureront jusqu’à lundi soir dans le territoire au bâti ravagé par la guerre.

title: En Chine, l’industrialisation à marche forcée de l’élevage porcin, née d’une épidémie, est aujourd’hui menacée
summary: Après l’importante épizootie de peste porcine de 2018, le pays a massivement industrialisé l’élevage pour assurer son autosuffisance alimentaire. Ce modèle d’usines géantes, qui a éliminé les petits éleveurs, est désormais fragilisé par la surproduction.

title: VIDEO - L’année de Donald Trump en images
summary: « Le Monde » raconte en vidéo la première année de Donald Trump, de retour à la Maison Blanche. Une année qui a reconfiguré la politique américaine et ses relations avec le monde.

title: Guerre en Ukraine : Volodymyr Zelensky se rend en Floride pour s’assurer du soutien de Donald Trump
summary: Quatre jours après avoir dévoilé un « projet d’accord » négocié avec les Américains pour mettre fin à la guerre, le président ukrainien doit rencontrer Donald Trump, dimanche, en Floride. Son objectif est à la fois de discuter des points qui font encore débat et de montrer que l’obstacle à la paix vient de Moscou et non de Kiev.

title: Dans le sillage d’Elon Musk, la Silicon Valley se prépare à la révolution des robots
summary: La robotique humanoïde suscite un engouement grandissant dans la tech californienne, portée par les prophéties du patron de Tesla. Nombre d’experts de ces technologies soulignent toutefois que le passage de l’IA au monde physique reste semé d’obstacles technologiques et logistiques.

title: « 2025, l’année où l’Europe a affaibli l’Ukraine en abandonnant la bande de Gaza »
summary: L’Union européenne peut d’autant moins résister aux coups portés par Donald Trump au droit international en Ukraine qu’elle a elle-même avalisé de telles violations à Gaza, relève dans sa chronique Jean-Pierre Filiu.

title: En Centrafrique, Etat failli et menacé par les groupes armés, un scrutin présidentiel sous haute surveillance
summary: Le président sortant, Faustin-Archange Touadéra, qui s’est appuyé sur des forces russes et rwandaises pour reprendre le contrôle du territoire centrafricain, est le grand favori de l’élection présidentielle organisée ce dimanche. La modification de la Constitution, en 2023, lui permet de rester au pouvoir indéfiniment.

title: Israeli tech sector saw rise in staff seeking relocation abroad due to war
summary:
Israeli tech sector saw rise in staff seeking relocation abroad due to war

Requests to relocate abroad by Israelis working at multinational companies operating in Israel rose in the past year in reaction to the war on Gaza, a report showed on Sunday.

The Israel Advanced Technology Industries Association (IATI) found that 53 percent of companies reported an increase in relocation requests from Israeli employees, noting this was "a trend that may, over time, harm the local innovation engine and Israel's technological leadership."

The tech sector accounts for about 20 percent of Israel's GDP, 15 percent of its jobs and more than half of its exports. The hundreds of multinationals in Israel include Microsoft, Intel, Nvidia, Amazon, Meta and Apple.

In its annual report, IATI also said some multinational companies are examining the transfer of investments and activities to other countries.

"In some cases, companies that faced disruptions in supply chains found alternatives outside Israel during the war, and when these proved efficient, there is a risk that activity will not fully return," said the report.

At the same time, it added, there has been an increase in demand for relocation among senior executives and families, with more employees applying for positions outside Israel.

Still, the report noted that multinationals view the Israeli tech ecosystem through a long-term lens and many firms have thrived during the war.

Reporting by Reuters

title: Israel’s Ben Gvir pushes bill to ban Islamic call to prayer
summary:
Israel’s Ben Gvir pushes bill to ban Islamic call to prayer

Israeli minister Itamar Ben Gvir’s party is advancing new legislation to restrict the Islamic call to prayer in mosques.

In a statement issued on Sunday, the Jewish Power party said it was working on a bill that would ban the call to prayer unless it is licensed by the state.

Approval would depend on criteria set by the authorities, including volume levels, noise-reduction measures, a mosque’s location, its proximity to residential areas and the impact on nearby residents.

The draft law was submitted by National Security Committee chair Zvika Fogel and seeks to curb what he described as the “unreasonable noise” of the muezzin, the person who calls Muslims to prayer.

Palestinian citizens of Israel have condemned the proposed bill, rejecting claims that mosque calls to prayer constitute a noise problem.

They say the legislation is another manifestation of the Israeli government’s push to erase Palestinian religious and cultural identity.

“This is not about noise. The call to prayer is not noise,” Khaled Zabarqa, a Lod-based human rights lawyer and activist, told Middle East Eye.

Read more: Israel’s Ben Gvir pushes bill to ban Islamic call to prayer

title: Israel’s Ben Gvir pushes bill to ban Islamic call to prayer
summary:
Israel’s Ben Gvir pushes bill to ban Islamic call to prayer

Submitted by Lubna Masarwa on Sun, 12/28/2025 - 13:58
Draft law would allow police to shut down mosque loudspeakers and impose heavy fines, which Palestinians say target their identity
The 18th-century Ottoman-period al-Jazzar Mosque, also known as the 'White Mosque', is pictured in the old walled town of Acre in northern Israel on 1 October 2024 (AFP/Ahmad Gharabli)
Off

Israeli minister Itamar Ben Gvir’s party is advancing new legislation to restrict the Islamic call to prayer in mosques.

In a statement issued on Sunday, the Jewish Power party said it was working on a bill that would ban the call to prayer unless it is licensed by the state.

Approval would depend on criteria set by the authorities, including volume levels, noise-reduction measures, a mosque’s location, its proximity to residential areas and the impact on nearby residents.

The draft law was submitted by National Security Committee chair Zvika Fogel and seeks to curb what he described as the “unreasonable noise” of the muezzin, the person who calls Muslims to prayer.

Palestinian citizens of Israel have condemned the proposed bill, rejecting claims that mosque calls to prayer constitute a noise problem.

They say the legislation is another manifestation of the Israeli government’s push to erase Palestinian religious and cultural identity.

“This is not about noise. The call to prayer is not noise,” Khaled Zabarqa, a Lod-based human rights lawyer and activist, told Middle East Eye.

“The call to prayer has existed for hundreds of years and has been recited daily since Israel was established. It did not suddenly become a noise problem,” he said. 

How Zionism is fuelling a religious war over al-Aqsa Mosque
Read More »

Instead, Zabarqa argued, the bill forms part of a broader effort to Judaise public space across Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories by removing symbols of non-Jewish identity.

“The call to prayer is a symbol of the religious and national identity of Palestinians inside Israel,” he said.

“It reminds them, and the world, that this land has an identity with deep roots, history and civilisation.”

Under the proposal, police officers could order the immediate shutdown of loudspeakers if the conditions are breached. Continued violations would allow officers to confiscate the equipment.

The penalties outlined in the bill are steep. Installing or operating loudspeakers without a permit would carry a fine of 50,000 shekels ($15,660). Violating permit conditions would result in a 10,000-shekel ($3,100) fine.

'Religious fanaticism'

In its explanatory note, the Jewish Power party described noise from mosques as a “health hazard” and claimed existing laws do not provide sufficient tools to address the issue.

Efforts to restrict or ban the Muslim call to prayer in Israel are not new.

In 2017, a similar bill seeking to ban the use of loudspeakers for the call to prayer passed a first reading in the Israeli parliament, the Knesset, but was never enacted.

Last year, Ben Gvir instructed police to prevent mosques from broadcasting the call to prayer, saying it “disturbs” Jewish residents.

Commenting on the latest draft bill, Ben Gvir said the call to prayer was, in many areas, “unreasonable noise” that harms residents’ health and quality of life.

“This is a phenomenon that cannot be accepted,” he said, adding that the legislation would grant police powers they currently lack.

'The assault on mosques... constitutes a direct confrontation with the beliefs of our people'

- Sheikh Kamal Khatib, Palestinian imam

Fogel echoed those remarks.

“A muezzin using an unusually loud volume is not a religious issue,” he said. “It is a matter of public health and quality of life. Residents cannot continue to suffer from systematic legal violations.”

Kamal al-Khatib, former deputy head of the now-banned Islamic Movement in Israel, said that despite repeated past attempts to restrict the call to prayer, the current proposal is particularly dangerous because it seeks to enshrine the ban in law.

Khatib, who is also an imam at a mosque in his hometown of Kafr Kanna, described the move as another chapter in what he called a religious war against Muslims in Israel.

“This comes amid a wave of religious fanaticism that has swept Israeli society,” he told MEE.

“Ben Gvir is nothing more than one manifestation of this fanaticism. The assault on mosques - whether through restricting the call to prayer, banning it altogether, or imposing heavy fines - constitutes a direct confrontation with the beliefs of our people.”

He said any restriction on the call to prayer must be categorically rejected.

“The call to prayer is a religious rite that existed before Ben Gvir and before [Prime Minister Benjamin] Netanyahu, and it will remain after them, God willing,” he added.

48 Palestinians
Jerusalem
News

0
Update Date
Mon, 05/04/2020 - 21:19
Update Date Override

title: Seized from Gaza hospital, Dr Hussam Abu Safiya still held by Israel a year on
summary:
Seized from Gaza hospital, Dr Hussam Abu Safiya still held by Israel a year on

Dr Hussam Abu Safiya, a 52-year-old Palestinian doctor, has spent a year in Israeli detention without charge or trial after Israeli forces seized him during a raid on a Gaza hospital.

Israeli troops kidnapped Abu Safiya on 27 December 2024 after storming Kamal Adwan Hospital in northern Gaza and forcing its evacuation.

The assault rendered the medical facility inoperable. Israel has held him ever since under its so-called “illegal combatant” law, which permits indefinite detention without charges and denies detainees access to evidence against them.

An Israeli court in Beersheba extended Abu Safiya’s detention for six months in March 2025 and again in October 2025, keeping him imprisoned despite no charges ever being brought against him.

Family members and rights advocates say Israeli authorities have subjected Abu Safiya to torture and degrading treatment.

Read more: Seized from Gaza hospital, Dr Hussam Abu Safiya still held by Israel a year on

title: Arab League holds emergency meeting over Israel's recognition of Somaliland
summary:
Arab League holds emergency meeting over Israel's recognition of Somaliland

The Arab League convened for an emergency meeting of permanent representatives on Sunday at the request of Somalia to discuss Israeli recognition of the Somaliland region. 

The meeting was held at the League's headquarters in Cairo and chaired by the UAE. 

Israel's decision to become the first country to recognise the breakaway region has been condemned by a string of countries. 

A statement condemning the recognition was signed jointly by Jordan, Egypt, Algeria, Comoros, Djibouti, Gambia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, the Maldives, Nigeria, Oman, Pakistan, Palestine, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Somalia, Sudan, Turkey, Yemen, and the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC). 

Somaliland has been part of the unified Somali Republic since 1960, but declared its independence in 1991 and established a de facto state.

Although it has had unofficial diplomatic relations with several countries, its sovereignty had not been recognised by any permanent UN member state until this week.

On Monday, the UN Security Council is set to convene an emergency session to discuss Israel's recognition.

title: Video: Sea water floods tents in southern Gaza
summary:
Video: Sea water floods tents in southern Gaza

Displaced Palestinians near Khan Younis were woken up on Sunday by sea water gushing into their tents as heavy rainfall and a storm batters the region.

Gaza’s civil defence said two persons, including a seven-year-old boy, were killed in the past two days due to bad weather. pic.twitter.com/o5rHM92gcY

— Middle East Eye (@MiddleEastEye) December 28, 2025

title: Israeli settlers cut down 40 olive trees overnight in Jerusalem
summary:
Israeli settlers cut down 40 olive trees overnight in Jerusalem

Israeli settlers cut down around 40 olive trees overnight in occupied East Jerusalem, according to Wafa news agency.

Witnesses told Wafa that a group of Israeli settlers stormed the town of Mukhmas before deliberately destroying the trees.

Olive trees are a key source of income for Palestinian families. Israeli attacks on agriculture, including olive trees, have increased in recent years. 

Elsewhere, Wafa reported that Israeli settlers set fire to a vehicle belonging to a Palestinian in the town of Huwara in the occupied West Bank and sprayed racist graffiti on the owner's home.

title: Morning update
summary:
Morning update

Good morning Middle East Eye readers,

Here are the latest updates from Gaza, where Israel continues to violate the ceasefire more than two months after it came into effect:

  • Strong winds tore apart and uprooted worn tents on Sunday, displacing entire families and leaving them exposed amid dire humanitarian conditions. 

  • A Palestinian woman was killed when a wall of a war-damaged house collapsed on to a tent near Gaza City’s port, according to the civil defence. 

  • Meanwhile, Israeli artillery shelled eastern Gaza City, while air strikes hit areas east of Khan Younis and al-Bureij refugee camp in central Gaza.

title: Evening recap
summary:
Evening recap

Our live blog will shortly be closing until tomorrow morning.

Here are the day's key developments:

  • The death toll from Israel's genocidal war on Gaza has risen to 71,266, the Palestinian health ministry reported on Saturday.

  • In the past 48 hours, four people were killed by Israeli fire, while the bodies of 25 others were recovered and taken to hospitals.

  • Since the ceasefire in October, at least 414 people have been killed by Israeli fire, the ministry added.

  • The director of the Palestinian health ministry in Gaza reported that there was a 40-percent drop in births in the strip and a sharp rise in miscarriages compared with last year, blaming malnutrition and restricted medical supplies.

  • The Palestinian Journalists Syndicate said on Saturday that Israeli attacks on Palestinian journalists have expanded beyond killings, injuries, arrests and restrictions on coverage to include the systematic targeting of their families.

  • The findings, based on documentation by the syndicate’s Freedoms Committee, show that attacks on journalists’ families have become a repeated and organised pattern across 2023, 2024 and 2025.

  • The committee recorded the deaths of about 706 relatives of journalists in the Gaza Strip during that period, stressing that the scale and consistency of the attacks indicate they are not the result of random wartime conditions.

  • Municipalities in northern Gaza say Israeli forces have turned the area into a disaster zone by continuing to block the entry of water, fuel, spare parts and reconstruction materials, deepening the collapse of basic services and the humanitarian crisis.

  • France has condemned Israeli gunfire in southern Lebanon that slightly injured a United Nations peacekeeper, describing it as part of a pattern of recent incidents targeting UN forces.

title: Seized from a Gaza hospital, Dr Hussam Abu Safiya still held by Israel a year on
summary:
Seized from a Gaza hospital, Dr Hussam Abu Safiya still held by Israel a year on

Submitted by MEE staff on Sat, 12/27/2025 - 23:18
Rights groups demand freedom for Abu Safiya, held by Israel without charge and subjected to torture
Dr Hussam Abu Safiya, director of Kamal Adwan Hospital in Gaza, has been detained by Israel since 27 December 2024 (X)
Off

Dr Hussam Abu Safiya, a 52-year-old Palestinian doctor, has spent a year in Israeli detention without charge or trial after Israeli forces seized him during a raid on a Gaza hospital.

Israeli troops kidnapped Abu Safiya on 27 December 2024 after storming Kamal Adwan Hospital in northern Gaza and forcing its evacuation.

The assault rendered the medical facility inoperable. Israel has held him ever since under its so-called “illegal combatant” law, which permits indefinite detention without charges and denies detainees access to evidence against them.

An Israeli court in Beersheba extended Abu Safiya’s detention for six months in March 2025 and again in October 2025, keeping him imprisoned despite no charges ever being brought against him.

Family members and rights advocates say Israeli authorities have subjected Abu Safiya to torture and degrading treatment.

In July, lawyer Ghaid Ghanem Qassem revealed that Safiya had lost over a third of his bodyweight in detention in Israel's notorious Ofer prison, was being brutally beaten and that his repeated requests for medical attention had been refused.

He also suffers from serious health conditions, including pre-existing heart disease, high blood pressure, impaired vision and scabies, yet has received no adequate medical care or specialist assessment.

The Palestinian Forum in Britain has launched the “Red Ribbons Campaign” to demand Abu Safiya’s release, alongside all Palestinians held in Israeli prisons. Campaigners held a vigil in London on Saturday, calling attention to his case and to the wider system of mass detention.

The Red Ribbons Campaign held a vigil in London today to demand the release of Palestinian prisoners held in Israeli jails, including Dr Hussam Abu Safiya, who has been detained by Israel for almost a year.

The Red Ribbons Campaign is calling for the release of more than 9,100… pic.twitter.com/Rj0DsRTe59

— Middle East Eye (@MiddleEastEye) December 27, 2025

The campaign says Israel currently holds more than 9,100 Palestinians, including over 450 women and children, many without charge or trial.

Abu Safiya had refused to leave Kamal Adwan Hospital despite repeated Israeli attacks, choosing to remain with patients and fellow medical staff.

Israeli forces later surrounded the hospital and expelled everyone inside. Since his arrest, Israel has transferred him between detention centres, including the notorious Sde Teiman facility and Ofer Prison, where supporters say abuse has continued.

Speaking to Al Jazeera via Zoom from Kazakhstan, where the family fled last month, Abu Safiya’s eldest son, Ilyas, said his father’s only “crime” was being a doctor.

Ilyas said the family stayed at the hospital throughout the attacks, even though his mother, Albina, holds Kazakh citizenship and could have left Gaza. On 26 October 2024, Israeli shelling killed Ilyas’s brother Ibrahim, 20, inside the hospital.

“The entire medical staff cried in grief for [my father] and for Ibrahim,” Ilyas said.

Israel's genocide in Gaza

title: Israeli forces advance into Syrian village in northern Quneitra
summary:
Israeli forces advance into Syrian village in northern Quneitra

Israeli occupation forces moved into the Syrian village of Taranga on Saturday, advancing towards the outskirts of Jabatha al-Khashab in the northern countryside of Quneitra, Syrian state media reported.

According to the Syrian Arab News Agency (SANA), a unit made up of six Israeli military vehicles entered from the direction of Tulul al-Humr. The convoy passed through the area between Beit Jann and Hadar before reaching Taranga and continuing towards Jabatha al-Khashab.

SANA said the vehicles were seen on the southern edge of Jabatha al-Khashab and on one of the elevated areas overlooking the town. The incursion coincided with the presence of a drone flying over the area, before the force later moved towards the village of Ufania in the province’s northern countryside.

A day earlier, Israeli occupation forces shelled the eastern Tel al-Ahmar area in southern Quneitra, firing three rounds and opening machine gun and medium weapons fire, according to the report

title: Israel systematically targets families of Palestinian journalists: Report
summary:
Israel systematically targets families of Palestinian journalists: Report

The Palestinian Journalists Syndicate said on Saturday that Israeli attacks on Palestinian journalists have expanded beyond killings, injuries, arrests and restrictions on coverage to include the systematic targeting of their families.

In a report released, the union said Israeli forces have increasingly targeted the relatives of journalists in what it described as a deliberate effort to turn journalism into an existential threat, forcing families to pay the price for a loved one’s work.

The findings, based on documentation by the syndicate’s Freedoms Committee, show that attacks on journalists’ families have become a repeated and organised pattern across 2023, 2024 and 2025. The committee recorded the deaths of about 706 relatives of journalists in the Gaza Strip during that period, stressing that the scale and consistency of the attacks indicate they are not the result of random wartime conditions.

According to the committee, Israeli attacks killed about 436 relatives of journalists in 2023, followed by roughly 203 in 2024 and at least 67 more in 2025, even as many families were forcibly displaced and living in tents or makeshift shelters.

The report said the most recent case came just days ago, when recovery teams found the bodies of journalist Hiba Al-Abadla, her mother and around 15 members of the Al-Astal family. Israeli aircraft had bombed their home west of Khan Younis nearly two years earlier.

The syndicate said the figures show that hundreds of children, women and elderly people were killed solely because of a family member’s work in journalism, calling it a grave violation of international humanitarian and legal standards.

title: Three Iranian satellites launched into orbit on Russian rocket, state media says
summary:
In 2nd launch since July, Tehran says Paya, Kowsar and Zafar-2 satellites sent into space from Vostochny launchpad in eastern Russia

title: Hezbollah chief says disarming resistance serves US-Israeli project
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Hezbollah’s Secretary-General Sheikh Naim Qassem says that calls to disarm the resistance were part of a joint US-Israeli project, arguing that such demands served Israel rather than Lebanon, while Israeli attacks on the country continue.

title: Exclusive | Venezuelans unfazed by US military threats, stand firmly with govt.: Analyst
summary: Tehran, IRNA - Angelo Giuliano, a Swiss-Italian activist and political analyst, who recently travelled to Venezuela, says the people of the South American country are firmly backing their government against aggression and the war of words launched by the United States.

title: Any new enemy mischief will be met with more decisive response: President
summary: President Masoud Pezeshkian has warned that Iran will give a more decisive response to any act of mischief by the enemies.

title: Death of Bahram Beyzai loss for Iran's artistic and cultural community: President
summary: Tehran, IRNA — President Masoud Pezeshkian has offered his condolences over the passing of Bahram Beyzai, one of the pioneers of Iranian cinema and theatre.

title: Iran launches three domestically built satellites aboard Russian Soyuz rocket
summary: Moscow, IRNA – Iran has launched three domestically built satellites into space aboard a Russian Soyuz rocket.

title: Araghchi urges Yemeni factions to preserve unity, avoid division
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi urged Yemen’s political parties and groups to engage in dialogue to prevent the country’s weakening and fragmentation, stressing the need to preserve Yemen’s territorial integrity.

title: Russian FM calls for viable Palestinian State to address historical injustices
summary: Tehran, IRNA —Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has reiterated his country's support for the formation of a Palestinian State in order to achieve enduring peace and stability across the West Asia region.

title: Gaza health chief warns of population crisis amid targeted attacks on fertility centers
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Munir Al-Barsh, Director-General of Gaza’s Ministry of Health, has revealed that monthly births have plummeted by 40 percent over the past year, dropping from 26,000 to just 17,000, disclosing that fertility and IVF centers have been directly targeted by Israeli forces.

title: Shafiabad named world’s best tourism village in 2025
summary: The historic village of Shafiabad, near the city of Shahdad in Kerman Province, was named the world’s best tourism village in 2025 by UN Tourism, recognized for its castle, caravanserai, and unique location on the edge of the Lut Desert.

title: Iran, Qatar foreign ministers discuss regional developments, Yemen situation
summary: Tehran, IRNA – The foreign ministers of Iran and Qatar have held talks to review regional developments, with a particular focus on recent events in Yemen and the need to preserve the country’s territorial integrity.

title: Iran and Turkey underline expanding parliamentary relations
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Iran’s Ambassador in Ankara Mohammad Hassan Habibollahzadeh and Abdurrahim Dusak, the chairperson of the Turkish PUIC Group in the Subcommittee on Muslim Communities and Minorities, have stressed developing parliamentary relations.

title: Martyr Soleimani’s school of thought a clear path for resistance: Afghan foundation
summary: Mashhad, IRNA – The head of the Socio-Cultural Foundation of Afghan Residents in Iran has said that Martyr Qassem Soleimani sought the formation of an Islamic civilization based on unity and cohesion among Muslims; therefore, his school of thought represents a clear path for resistance movements.

title: Universities play key role in localizing advanced technology
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – Iran's minister of defense says academic centers play a leading role in indigenizing technologies, noting that solving strategic issues of country is impossible without relying on scientific capacity of universities.

title: Zionist regime police officer injured in Palestinian op.
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – An Israeli regime police officer was injured on Sunday in a suspected martyrdom-seeking operation by Palestinians involving a car ramming operation in occupied al-Quds, according to reports by Israeli media.

title: Pakistan opposes Hamas disarmament
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – Pakistan has said it is willing to contribute troops to an international force to restore peace in Gaza, but only if the mandate excludes the disarmament of Hamas, a key clause in the US 20-point peace plan.

title: "We won’t surrender and we’ll defend our land," Qassem says
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – Hezbollah Secretary General Sheikh Naim Qassem has declared the Islamic Resistance in Lebanon will not surrender to the foreign plots and will continue to defend the Lebanese lands against the potential Israeli aggression.

title: Iran puts 3 new remote-sensing satellites into orbit
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – Iran put three new remote-sensing satellites into orbit simultaneously, using a Russian launch pad on Sunday.

title: VIDEO: Snowfall blanketed several regions in Baneh
summary: KORDESTAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – Heavy snowfall in Baneh County, Kordestan province covered different district of the city and created difficulties for transportation in the town.

title: Araghchi stresses preserving Yemen's territorial integrity
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – Iranian Minister of Foreign Affairs Abbas Araghchi held a telephone call with the Yemen 's acting minister of foreign affairs and expatriates, Abdulwahid Abu Ras on Sunday.

title: Israel tightens siege on Qabatiya, moves to demolish homes
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – The Israeli army has continued its siege of Palestinian town of Qabatiya, south of Jenin in the northern occupied West Bank, escalating collective punishment measures that include home demolitions and sweeping military raids.

title: Hassan Rabbat public bathhouse
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – The photos show Hassan Rabbat public bathhouse in Isfahan which dates back to the Safavid era.

title: Staffer reacts to hacking of Netanyahu office chief's phone
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – A source in the Israeli Prime Minister's Office reacted to news published by the Handalah hacking group that the phone of Netanyahu's chief of staff was hacked.

title: HTS-led regime denounces Israeli recognition of Somaliland
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – The Foreign Ministry of Abu Mohammad Al-Jolani regime in Syria strongly condemned the Israeli recognition of Somaliland.

title: Iran’s petchem production capacity to hit 131.5m tons: NPC
summary: TEHRAN, Dec. 28 (MNA) – The chief executive of the National Petrochemical Company (NPC) says production capacity of petrochemical products will reach 131.5 million tons by the end of the country’s 7th Five-Year Socioeconomic and Cultural Development.

summary: اهواز – فرمانداران ایذه و مسجدسلیمان اعلام کردند: به‌دلیل بارش شدید باران و وقوع سیلاب، تمامی مدارس این دو شهرستان روز دوشنبه هشتم دی تعطیل خواهند بود.
